Hill Associates Classroom Files
ITT QuestionsVPN QuestionsAbout

March 27-29, 2023 - FDIC VPN & RA

Mar 23, 2023

Welcome to our class on VPNs and Remote access for the FDIC and other financial examiners. Here are are a few things to get you thinking about topics we’ll cover during the week:

  • A running list of questions about VPNs and related topics that I might ask if I were an examiner of banks. Since I’m a network geek, these are ones related to this class - there are certainly other good ones.

Monday March 27th

  • We’ll talk about VPN topics in class of course, but an entertaining introduction to some of them can be found in this video by Tom Scott.

  • You certainly already appreciate the role privacy plays in the financial sector. The Electronic Frontier Foundation has a longstanding relationship to issues related to privacy - which is, after all, the “P” in VPN. Their most recent update will give you a sense of how “privacy first” technologists and activists think, and also provides links to many VPN-adjacent resources.

  • The Economist’s 2021 book of the year - Privacy is Power by Carissa Véliz.

Tuesday March 28th

  • Yesterday I mentioned the OG of Internet Privacy herself, Shoshanna Zuboff, but neglected to link to her magnum opus. Carissa Véliz certainly read this book.

  • Incognito Mode on a web browser is a great way to keep what you’re doing away from prying eyes on your (or a shared) computer, but it doesn’t do anything to keep remote people from seeing what you’re doing. Here are a couple decent articles about this, one from Avast and one from Bitcatcha.

  • Yesterday I talked through the “Magic VPNs” example in the book, but here’s an animated recording of the same material that you can replay if you’d like.

  • The relationship between VPNs and ZTNA depends on who’s solution you’re talking about. This article from TechRadar does a decent job of explaining it without too much company marketing.

Wednesday March 29th

  • I must admit I love Cloudflare. Explainers like these, on Public Key Cryptography and SSL Certificates, are a big part of why I feel that way.

  • In case you wanted a bit more detail on how AES encryption works.

  • You can say this is a bit silly, but…well, it’s just awesome. The Manga Guide to Cryptography! I got a copy for Christmas, honest.

  • Christian asked a great question about how exactly the remote login I demonstrated works - there’s more to it than I thought! The answer (to a reasonable degree of detail) is located in the Unix man pages, like all good geeky answers.

  • Thanks to Paul for sending me a (rather unhinged, and on TikTok too!) video monologue from some dude hyperventilating about the RESTRICT act. I can’t say I liked his style, but that doesn’t mean he’s wrong. Here are some other points along similar lines:

    • Internet Governance calls it “the latest legislative atrocity to emerge from Washington.”
    • Lawfare also talks a bit about the DATA act.
    • My lovely EFF doesn’t care about TikTok much itself, rather points out that RESTRICT is just bad law.

I’m not saying you should contact your reps about this bill, but…

  • We probably didn’t talk about Remote Access Trojans (RATs) enough, so here’s a good article from Fortinet on the topic.

Remote Access Exercise Assignments

  • Group 1: Fortinet Work from Anywhere
  • Group 2: Palo Alto Global Protect
  • Group 3: SonicWall Secure Mobile Access
  • Group 4: Remote PC
  • Group 5: Cisco Secure Client
